    • Method Detail

      • calculateFrustumPlanes

        public static void calculateFrustumPlanes(Matrix4f mvp,
                                          Vector4f[] planes)
        Calculate the frustum planes of the given transformation matrix, which can be a projection matrix or a combined modelview-projection matrix, and store the result in the given planes vectors.

        Generally, this method computes the frustum planes in the local frame of any coordinate system that existed before the given mvp transformation was applied to it in order to yield homogeneous clipping space.

        Each of the six planes will be given as plane equations: a*x + b*y + c*z + d = 0, where the given Vector4f components will hold the (a, b, c, d) values of each plane equation. All plane equations will be normalized, meaning that (a, b, c) will be a unit vector.

        The plane normals, which are the (a, b, c) parameters, are directed "inwards" of the frustum. Any plane/point test using a*x + b*y + c*z + d therefore will yield a result greater than zero if the point is within the frustum (i.e. at the positive side of each frustum plane).

        Reference: Fast Extraction of Viewing Frustum Planes from the World-View-Projection Matrix

        Parameters:
        mvp - the transformation matrix whose frustum planes should be computed
        planes - holds the six vectors to store the plane equations in. The order of the array elements is: left, right, bottom, top, near and far

      • calculateFrustumPlanes

        public static void calculateFrustumPlanes(Matrix4d mvp,
                                          Vector4d[] planes)
        Calculate the frustum planes of the given transformation matrix, which can be a projection matrix or a combined modelview-projection matrix, and store the result in the given planes vectors.

        Generally, this method computes the frustum planes in the local frame of any coordinate system that existed before the given mvp transformation was applied to it in order to yield homogeneous clipping space.

        Each of the six planes will be given as plane equations: a*x + b*y + c*z + d = 0, where the given Vector4d components will hold the (a, b, c, d) values of each plane equation. All plane equations will be normalized, meaning that (a, b, c) will be a unit vector.

        The plane normals, which are the (a, b, c) parameters, are directed "inwards" of the frustum. Any plane/point test using a*x + b*y + c*z + d therefore will yield a result greater than zero if the point is within the frustum (i.e. at the positive side of each frustum plane).

        Reference: Fast Extraction of Viewing Frustum Planes from the World-View-Projection Matrix

        Parameters:
        mvp - the transformation matrix whose frustum planes should be computed
        planes - holds the six vectors to store the plane equations in. The order of the array elements is: left, right, bottom, top, near and far

      • calculateFrustumPlanes

        public static void calculateFrustumPlanes(Matrix4f mvp,
                                          Vector4f left,
                                          Vector4f right,
                                          Vector4f bottom,
                                          Vector4f top,
                                          Vector4f near,
                                          Vector4f far)
        Calculate the frustum planes of the given transformation matrix, which can be a projection matrix or a combined modelview-projection matrix, and store the result in the given left, right, bottom, top, near and far parameters.

        Generally, this method computes the frustum planes in the local frame of any coordinate system that existed before the given mvp transformation was applied to it in order to yield homogeneous clipping space.

        Each of the six planes left, right, bottom, top, near and far will be given as plane equations: a*x + b*y + c*z + d = 0, where the given Vector4f components will hold the (a, b, c, d) values of each plane equation. All plane equations will be normalized, meaning that (a, b, c) will be a unit vector.

        The plane normals, which are the (a, b, c) parameters, are directed "inwards" of the frustum. Any plane/point test using a*x + b*y + c*z + d therefore will yield a result greater than zero if the point is within the frustum (i.e. at the positive side of each frustum plane).

        Reference: Fast Extraction of Viewing Frustum Planes from the World-View-Projection Matrix

        Parameters:
        mvp - the transformation matrix whose frustum planes should be computed
        left - will hold the plane equation components of the left frustum plane
        right - will hold the plane equation components of the right frustum plane
        bottom - will hold the plane equation components of the bottom frustum plane
        top - will hold the plane equation components of the top frustum plane
        near - will hold the plane equation components of the near frustum plane
        far - will hold the plane equation components of the far frustum plane

      • calculateFrustumPlanes

        public static void calculateFrustumPlanes(Matrix4d mvp,
                                          Vector4d left,
                                          Vector4d right,
                                          Vector4d bottom,
                                          Vector4d top,
                                          Vector4d near,
                                          Vector4d far)
        Calculate the frustum planes of the given transformation matrix, which can be a projection matrix or a combined modelview-projection matrix, and store the result in the given left, right, bottom, top, near and far parameters.

        Generally, this method computes the frustum planes in the local frame of any coordinate system that existed before the given mvp transformation was applied to it in order to yield homogeneous clipping space.

        Each of the six planes left, right, bottom, top, near and far will be given as plane equations: a*x + b*y + c*z + d = 0, where the given Vector4d components will hold the (a, b, c, d) values of each plane equation. All plane equations will be normalized, meaning that (a, b, c) will be a unit vector.

        The plane normals, which are the (a, b, c) parameters, are directed "inwards" of the frustum. Any plane/point test using a*x + b*y + c*z + d therefore will yield a result greater than zero if the point is within the frustum (i.e. at the positive side of each frustum plane).

        Reference: Fast Extraction of Viewing Frustum Planes from the World-View-Projection Matrix

        Parameters:
        mvp - the transformation matrix whose frustum planes should be computed
        left - will hold the plane equation components of the left frustum plane
        right - will hold the plane equation components of the right frustum plane
        bottom - will hold the plane equation components of the bottom frustum plane
        top - will hold the plane equation components of the top frustum plane
        near - will hold the plane equation components of the near frustum plane
        far - will hold the plane equation components of the far frustum plane

                          Vector3f v3,
                          Vector3f dest)
        Calculate the normal of a surface defined by points v1, v2 and v3 and store it in dest.
        Parameters:
        v1 - the first position
        v2 - the second position
        v3 - the third position
        dest - will hold the result

      • tangent

        public static void tangent(Vector3f v1,

                           Vector2f uv2,
                           Vector3f v3,
                           Vector2f uv3,
                           Vector3f dest)
        Calculate the surface tangent for the three supplied vertices and UV coordinates and store the result in dest.
        Parameters:
        v1 - XYZ of first vertex
        uv1 - UV of first vertex
        v2 - XYZ of second vertex
        uv2 - UV of second vertex
        v3 - XYZ of third vertex
        uv3 - UV of third vertex
        dest - the tangent will be stored here
